document.text: Virginias Man of the Year in Forestry for 1953 is John Cleve land Lucy, a native and long resi dent of Brunswick County, Virginia. A dealer in pulpwood and standing timber, he is president of J. C. Lucy, Inc., and of the Brunswick Box Company, Inc. A public spirited citi zen, he is a member of the Bruns wick County Board of Supervisors, a director of the Farmers and Merchants Bank and of the Brick and Tile Corporation of Lawrence- ville, master of Brunswick Lodge No. 52, F.  A. M., and member of the Lawrenceville Lions Club, Chamber of Commerce, Order of the Moose. Knights of Pythias, Scottish Rite South Hill Shrine Club and Acca Temple. As a public spirted citizen and business man, Mr. Lucy has been a strong and influencial supporter of the Virginia Forest Service. He has persuaded many landowners to have their timber marked for thinning rather than to let it be cut clear out. He was very helpful in securing the adoption of the Seed Tree Law in his county, and strongly defended that law when efforts were made to have it repealed. He has worked closely with the chief fire warden.. helping him to obtain needed equip ment, financing county-wide Keep Virginia Green organization dinner meetings, and arranging for fire prevention publicity through adver tisements and civic club programs. As a member of Virginia Forests, Inc., Mr. Lucy is chairman of the Brunswick County Forestry Com mittee. He has arranged county-wide meetings of industry representatives to get them more interested in bet ter forestry, has for the past three years helped to secure sufficient Smokey Bear comic books and fire prevention book covers to provide one for each school child in the coun ty, and has personally seen to it that these were distributed to every school in the county. As an individual, Mr. Lucy was one of the first pulpwood dealers in Virginia to become genuinely inter ested in good forestry.. Not only did he preach it for others, .he put it into practice on his own property.
